growing.zone: 9-11 (grown as annual or indoor plant in cooler zones)
growing.soil: Rich, well-draining soil with good organic matter

planting.whenToPlant: Plant after last frost when soil is warm; can start indoors earlier
planting.propagation: By division or root cuttings; can also start from seed but less common
planting.depth: Plant divisions or root cuttings about 2 inches deep

careAndMaintenance.pruning: Trim stalks regularly to encourage bushier growth and remove dead foliage
careAndMaintenance.overwintering: In cooler zones, bring indoors or grow as annual; mulch heavily if left outside in borderline zones

harvestingAndUsage.whenToHarvest: Harvest stalks when at least 1/2 inch thick and before flowering
harvestingAndUsage.howToHarvest: Cut stalks near the base with sharp scissors or pruners
harvestingAndUsage.preservation: Can be used fresh, or chopped and dried; freeze chopped stalks for long-term storage
harvestingAndUsage.edibleOrToxic: Safe for culinary use; commonly used in teas, soups, and dishes
harvestingAndUsage.culinary: Widely used in Southeast Asian cuisine; adds citrusy flavor to soups, curries, and teas

medicinal.Digestive Aid: Used as a soothing tea to relieve indigestion, bloating, and stomach cramps.
medicinal.Antimicrobial: Has natural antimicrobial properties, helpful for minor infections and oral hygiene.
medicinal.Anti-inflammatory & Pain Relief: Traditionally used to reduce inflammation and alleviate headaches and muscle pain.
medicinal.Anxiety & Sleep Aid: Lemongrass tea is calming and often consumed to reduce anxiety and promote sleep.

harvestingAndUsage.aromatic: Strong lemon scent used in aromatherapy, candles, and natural insect repellents

ecologicalInfo.wildlifeResistance: Generally not favored by deer or rabbits due to strong aroma

funFacts: Lemongrass oil is used in perfumes, soaps, and insect repellents.
